DEBATE.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN NATIONAL RAILWAYS COMMISSION AMENDMENT BILL 1987

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill received from the Senate, and read a first time.
Ordered that the second reading be made an order of the day for the next sitting.
Bill received from the Senate, and read a first time.
Ordered that the second reading be made an order of the day for the next sitting.
Bill presented by Mr Barry Jones, for Mr Kerin, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jones The Hon B.O.

TALKER.NAME: Mr BARRY JONES
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Science and Small Business)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

The purpose of the Bill is to provide for the establishment of the Australian Horticultural Corporation (AHC). The Bill forms one essential element of the package of measures being introduced primarily to enhance the capacity of the horticultural industries to expand exports. The other measures in the package are the Horticultural Research and Development Corporation Bill, the Horticultural Policy Council Bill, the Horticultural Levy Bill, the Horticultural Levy Collection Bill, the Horticultural Export Charge Bill, the Horticultural Export Charge Collection Bill and the Australian Horticultural Corporation (Transitional Provisions and Consequential Amendments) Bill.

The package of Bills implements the institutional initiatives for the horticultural sector which form part of the Government's economic and rural policy statement of April 1986 and for which the Government has committed a total of $9m over five years to assist in their establishment and early operation. The sector's output in 1985-86 was valued at some $2 billion, with exports amounting to around $400m in that year. While the horticultural sector has achieved significant increases in exports in recent years, opportunities exist for further substantial increases. For the sector's full export potential to be realised, however, there needs to be a more co-ordinated and sustained activity both in horticultural products marketing and in research.

The Bills relating to the two corporations provide for the establishment of complementary institutions which will be required, as their main task, to assist the horticultural industries to develop their export marketing and research efforts. The four Bills dealing with product levies and export charges provide for funds to be raised from participating industries to help finance the ongoing activities of the two corporations. The Horticultural Policy Council Bill fits into the package by providing the means for developing more consistent and comprehensive policies at the national level for the horticultural industries. The Council will be funded wholly by the Commonwealth for five years. Funding and the Council's continuance will be reviewed in its fifth year of operation.

The Australian Horticultural Corporation (Transitional Provisions and Consequential Amendments) Bill provides for things such as the transfer to the AHC of staff, assets and liabilities from the Australian Apple and Pear Corporation on its abolition.

Many views were conveyed to the Government by industry organisations and other groups throughout Australia during the extensive consultation process that was undertaken on the initiatives. These views were carefully considered and many of the suggestions which were put forward are now reflected in the Bills before the House. The Government believes that, in their present form, the Bills address constructively the needs of the industries and that the horticultural sector will benefit significantly from these new institutions.

Participation in the AHC by horticultural industries is voluntary. In the case of industries currently covered by statutory marketing arrangements, namely the canned fruits, dried fruits and apple and pear industries, the situation is as follows: for canned fruits, the Government has decided that the statutory marketing powers of the Australian Canned Fruits Corporation are to be extended by one year only, to December 1988, and that the Corporation be wound up in 1989. Whether or not any of its other functions would be passed over to the AHC is a matter for consideration by the industry. The question of merging the Australian Dried Fruits Corporation with the AHC is being deferred until 1988. In the meantime the Minister for Primary Industry and Energy (Mr Kerin) is currently exploring with the industry the question of a separate corporation in line with the Government's policy on primary industry statutory marketing authorities.

The Minister advised the Australian Apple and Pear Growers Association in May 1987 that he considered it would be in the best interests of the industry if it were encompassed in the AHC from the outset. The Minister has had further consultations with that organisation's executive since then and, as a result, modifications to the details of the proposals were made to accommodate the industry's concerns.

TALK.START.PARA: —Good decision.
—What would we expect from a Minister such as John Kerin?
—Where is he?

—Representing the nation. At its annual conference in July 1987 the Association agreed to participation in the AHC. The inclusion of apple and pear activities under the AHC makes the Australian Apple and Pear Corporation redundant. The Bill thus provides for the repeal of the principal and amending Apple and Pear Corporation Acts and, as I mentioned earlier, there is an associated Bill which deals with transitional and other provisions arising from the abolition of this Corporation.

SPEECH.PARA: I turn now to the specific provisions of the Bill.
Objects, Functions and Powers

The objects, functions and powers of the AHC are set out in part II, division 1 of the Bill and additional powers are described in part V. The principal object of the AHC is to assist Australian horticultural industries to achieve their full potential in overseas markets. To achieve this it will encourage, facilitate and co-ordinate export activities, and provide a link from exporting and marketing back to growers to encourage production in line with market needs. It will complement, not replace, the marketing efforts of private exporters.

An important subsidiary object of the AHC is to contribute to the development of horticultural production and marketing within Australia. In particular, it will be able to undertake domestic promotional activities on behalf of horticultural industries and, in this respect, will continue to handle the extensive domestic promotion relating to apples and pears.

Not all horticultural industries will require the same services from the AHC and, for that reason, the Bill provides flexibility for the AHC in meeting varying industry needs; it also empowers the Corporation to carry out work for indivi- duals and groups on a fee-for-service basis on the one hand, and on the other, it will have the power to appoint agents to perform any tasks on its behalf.

In addition to the range of powers that will enable the Corporation to undertake general activities for and on behalf of industries, the Bill provides it with export trading powers. These powers are, however, subject to the written approval of the Minister, and the Government is firmly of the view that they would be applied only in circumstances where there is general support from the relevant industry. To facilitate such export trading, the Corporation may buy and sell horticultural products and it may enter into contracts concerning transport and insurance.

In part V of the Bill the AHC will also be empowered, if appropriate, to control exports and provide for licensing arrangements. The exercise of such powers is to be fully consistent with the Corporation's primary object of assisting the horticultural industries to achieve their full potential in export markets. The Government will agree to the making of regulations and ministerial orders for this purpose only if it is satisfied that this is the case and that the controls are in the best interests of the industry.
Organisational Structure

The Government's policy for primary industry statutory marketing authorities provides that it is not appropriate for boards of such authorities to have as members persons representing various sectors of industry but rather that the members should have the skills appropriate to their corporate responsibilities. In conformity with that policy, the Bill provides that membership of the AHC is based on qualifications and experience in various specific fields of endeavour.

Part II, division 2 of the Bill provides that the membership will comprise an independent Chairperson, one Government member, the Managing Director and six other members. The six other members are to be selected on the basis of their expertise in one or more of a number of fields such as horticultural growing, horticultural exporting, business management, finance and marketing. Members, other than the Managing Director, will be appointed by the Minister on a part time basis; except for the Government member, the appointments will be for periods of up to three years but members will be eligible for re-appointment. Under this provision, membership terms can be staggered to ensure that the Corporation always has some members with experience of its activities and knowledge of current issues. The Managing Director will be appointed by the Board but with the terms and conditions of employment being approved by the Minister.

The diversity of products and industries in the horticultural sector means the Board will need product-specific advice. Part II, division 8 of the Bill therefore empowers the Corporation to establish such specialist committees as it considers necessary. The number of product group committees and the range of products a particular committee might cover will be decided by the Corporation after consultation with the industries participating in the AHC. Given its size and importance, the apple and pear industry can confidently anticipate that there would be a separate committee for its products; and so, too, can the citrus industry, which has given its firm commitment to participate in the AHC.

The members of a product group committee will be appointed by the Corporation and comprise a chairperson, who is to be a member of the Corporation Board, and from three to five other members with product-specific expertise in areas which are, in general terms, the same as those laid down for Corporation members. As it is the Board of the Corporation that is accountable for actions performed on its behalf, product group committees will not be autonomous. However, the Corporation will be empowered to delegate its powers to the committees and I would expect, for example-indeed the Minister would expect-that the bulk of any activity undertaken on domestic promotion would be so delegated. This will free the Board to focus on the broader, general, export policy issues.
Selection Procedures

Part III of the Bill provides for the establishment of the Australian Horticultural Corporation Selection Committee. The function of the Committee will be to identify and nominate persons with expertise in one or more specified fields for appointment by the Minister of Corporation members. The Selection Committee will comprise a chairperson selected by the Minister, six members appointed from nominations put forward by relevant horticultural producer organisations and one member nominated by horticultural exporting interests.

In the longer term, when levy arrangements have been put in place, national organisations representing those industries which provide the levy proceeds for funding the Corporation will be the ones to be prescribed as eligible to provide producer nominations. However, as the apple and pear industry is the only industry for which levies will be collected for the AHC from its outset, and as the citrus industry is, so far, the only other industry which has given a firm commitment to participate and contribute by way of levies, the Government has decided that their respective national organisations will be invited to furnish the bulk of nominees for the first round of appointments to the AHC Selection Committee. Thus, the Australian Apple and Pear Growers Association will be invited to furnish nominees for three positions and the Australian Citrus Growers Federation for one position. The Australian Horticultural Growers Council will also be invited to provide two nominees and, in recognition of the Corporation's export focus, one nominee is to be put forward by a horticultural exporter organisation. All these organisations will be prescribed for this purpose. It is intended that the Australian Horticultural Growers Council, before furnishing its nominations, will be required to consult with industry organisations and to have particular regard to the views of those industries wishing to participate in the Corporation at an early stage.

Part IV of the Bill provides for the establishment and operation of product group selection committees. These are to consist of the Chairperson of the Corporation Selection Committee, two Corporation members and from three to six nominated members. The number of nominated members in each case will be determined by the Corporation in consultation with the relevant industry organisations. The Bill provides for the Corporation to appoint the members-other than the chairperson-of a product group selection committee. The nominated members are to be appointed from nominees furnished by the relevant industry organisations. The arrangements mean that those industries which provide levy or export charge proceeds for funding the Corporation will play a major part in determining who will be on the AHC Selection Committee and on product group committees.
Cost and Accounting Matters

The Bill also puts in place provisions which deal with the manner in which financial transactions and costs are to be treated. To facilitate financial accountability and protect the interests of participating industries, funds provided by each industry will be held by the Corporation in separate accounts. In this regard, the assets and liabilities of the Australian Apple and Pear Corporation will be transferred immediately to a separate account on commencement of the AHC's operation. In consultation with different participating industries, the AHC will need to put in place mechanisms to ensure that funds derived from one industry will not be used to support activities for other industries but this will not preclude agreed joint-industry funding for particular projects, should this be required. All participating industries will need to contribute to meeting the basic overheads of the AHC. The sharing of these costs will be determined by the Board of the Corporation on an equitable basis, with the composition of the costs being identified.

An important consideration that has been of particular interest to the horticultural industries is that of cost. As I have already mentioned, the Corporation will be a commercially oriented organisation. Its structure will reflect industry requirements. For example, separate product group committees will only be established, where justified, in consultation with the relevant industry or industries. Similarly, the Corporation will be able to respond in terms of staffing and other resources as needs dictate. Over the longer term, the Corporation will be funded fully by industry and the consultation and accountability requirements of the Bill will ensure that proper pressures are extended for its cost efficient and effective performance.

The Commonwealth has allocated to the Corporation $5.85m over five years to assist it to get programs of activities under way quickly. Pending the implementation of levy arrangements for those industries wishing to participate, some $300,000 a year of this may be used to defray basic overheads, thus presenting significant savings for participating industries in the early years whilst leaving a considerable pool of funds for commercial activities.
Planning and Accountability

Provisions in part II, division 3 of the Bill ensure that the Corporation will carry out its functions in a businesslike manner and spell out the basis for its relationship with the Minister. These require the Corporation to prepare a corporate plan with a five-year horizon, to be reviewed and extended annually. The corporate plan is to define the principal objectives of the Corporation, assess the industry outlook and outline the strategies it will pursue. Before preparing or revising the corporate plan the Corporation will be required to consult with eligible bodies. The Corporation will also be required to develop for each successive period an annual operational plan which sets out, among other things, the details of the strategies to be pursued by the Corporation in the coming year. Both the corporate and annual operating plans are to be submitted to the Minister for approval. In this way, the accountability arrangements with the Minister will focus on the strategies and longer term performance of the Corporation and free it from the need for constant reference to the Minister for approval of individual activities proposed.

Apart from its corporate and operational planning provisions, the Bill contains a number of accountability requirements which are designed to further ensure that the AHC will carry out its operations in a businesslike manner. These requirements are covered in part III, division 4 of the Bill. Not only will the Corporation be required to present an annual report covering its operations, including its audited financial statements for each financial year, to the Minister for tabling in the Parliament, but also to each eligible industry body. As well, the Corporation will be required to arrange with some individual, eligible industry bodies for the chairperson to attend either their next annual conference or a meeting of their executives. For other eligible industry bodies, the Corporation will be required to convene a meeting to which their representatives would be invited to attend. At such meetings the chairperson will be required to provide an address and to be questioned on the activities of the corporation as covered by the annual report and the Corporation's intended activities for the coming year. The horticultural sector has considerable potential to develop further, particularly in terms of exporting. This potential will be more readily realised if the sector is assisted by an appropriate organisational infrastructure. This Corporation is an important part of that infrastructure. I commend the Bill to honourable members. I do not think honourable members could say that the second reading speech has not been unsparing in detail. I now present the explanatory memorandum.
Debate (on motion by Mr Lloyd) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: HORTICULTURAL RESEARCH AND DEVELOPMENT CORPORATION BILL 1987

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Barry Jones, for Mr Kerin, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jones The Hon B.O.

TALKER.NAME: Mr BARRY JONES
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Science and Small Business)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

The purpose of the Horticultural Research and Development Corporation Bill 1987 is to provide for the establishment of a Horticultural Research and Development Corporation (HRDC) as part of the package of measures outlined in my second reading speech for the Australian Horticultural Corporation Bill 1987. It has been recognised that the horticultural sector has under-invested in research and development with continuing national programs having been few and far between. The Horticultural Research and Development Corporation provided for in this Bill is designed to overcome these problems by funding more, and by better co-ordinating, horticultural research and development. I turn now to the specific provisions of the Bill.
Objects, Functions and Powers

The objects, functions and powers of the HRDC are set out in part II, division 1 of the Bill. The Corporation's primary object is to improve production by, and market performance of, horticultural industries. This is to be achieved in three main ways; firstly, by identifying areas of horticultural research and development which are relevant to the needs of these industries; secondly, by improving the efficiency and effectiveness of horticultural research and development; and, thirdly, by encouraging the more effective use of the resources and skills available in the community, especially in the scientific community, for horticultural research and development.

The Corporation is also charged with developing awareness in the Australian horticultural industries as to the positive contribution that research and development can make to improving their efficiency and competitiveness. Industry diversity has meant that, due to the limited scope of their operations, smaller individual industries have had difficulties in identifying their potential for research. The Corporation will, in time, become a source of information for these industries with respect to the advantages that might exist for them.

The functions of the Corporation detailed by the Bill include evaluation of research and development plans and, of course, funding the carrying out by others, or, if appropriate, by itself carrying out, relevant research and development activities.

Subject to certain restrictions, the Corporation is to be empowered to do all things that are necessary to perform its functions. This includes fee-for-service charging, employing staff and accepting contributions. Importantly-I have asked the Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce not to use that word in second reading speeches and I stumbled over it here; but a lot of people around here say `importantly'. As a body corporate, it is important that it should be able to make applications for, and deal with patents, participate in joint ventures and enter into agreements for the carrying out of research and development projects by other persons.
Membership and Selection

Part II, division 2 of the Bill provides the composition of the Board of the Corporation. The nine-member Board will consist of an independent chairperson, one government member, the Executive Director and six other members. The six other members are to be selected on the basis of expertise in one or more fields such as growing or processing horticultural products, horticultural or other research and development, administration or marketing. These members are to be nominated by a selection committee as provided for in part III of the Bill.

Members, other than the Corporation-appointed Executive Director, will be appointed by the Minister on a part time basis. Except for the government member, appointments will be for periods of up to three years, but members will be eligible for re-appointment. Under this provision, membership terms can be staggered to ensure that the Corporation always has some members with experience of its activities and knowledge of current issues.

Part III of the Bill provides for the establishment of the Corporation Selection Committee. The function of that Committee will be to identify and nominate persons for appointment by the Minister of Corporation members based on one or more fields of expertise defined by the Bill. The Committee will consist of seven members. Four members, including the Chairperson, will be drawn from the existing Rural Industries Research Councils Selection Committee. The other three members will be nominated by eligible industry bodies for appointment by the Minister.

For the first round of appointments, the Government has decided that as the apple and pear industry is the only industry for which levies will be collected for the HRDC from its outset, and as the citrus industry is, so far, the only industry which has given a firm commitment to participate and contribute by way of levies, their respective national organisations will be invited to furnish one nominee each. The Australian Horticultural Growers Council will be invited to provide the other nominee. It is intended that the Council will be required to consult industry organisations before furnishing its nominee and to have particular regard to the views of those industries wishing to participate at an early stage. As other industries decide to participate in the arrangements they will become eligible industries and will have a say in the nomination process.
Finance

Part II, division 7 of the Bill deals with financial, accounting and auditing aspects of the Corporation's activities. A number of these matters warrant brief mention. The Corporation is to receive funds from industries through levy and export charge collections. As occurs with other rural industries research councils, the levies and charges collected for the Corporation will attract a matching dollar for dollar contribution from the Commonwealth of up to 0.5 per cent of the particular industry's gross value of production.

However, as the dispersed nature or other factors in some industries within the horticultural sector can result in their not being able to develop adequate levy arrangements, the Government is prepared to vary these matching arrangements.

TALK.START.PARA: —They just did with the wool industry.

—No, you are being political. This variation provides for the matching, by government, of eligible voluntary contributions made in respect of products not subject to levy but, as before, within the ceiling of the 0.5 per cent of the gross value of production of the particular industry. Such matching will be subject to appropriate guidelines to be issued by way of ministerial orders in due course.

SPEECH.PARA: It is also important to note that, in order to assist the Corporation to get programs under way quickly, the Government has allocated $1.25m for use by the Corporation over the first five years of its operation. This funding is not dependent on corresponding industry contributions being made during that period but, as such contributions are made, normal Commonwealth matching will be drawn from this allocation. Provision has also been made for contribution by different industries to be held in separate accounts. This will result in the identification of each industry's expenditure on research and development activities. However, such an accounting practice will not preclude cross-industry funding of projects, where this is considered appropriate by the Corporation and the industries involved.
Planning and Accountability

Provisions in part III, division 3 ensure that the Corporation maintains a high level of control and direction in the discharge of its functions. It will be required to develop a corporate research and development plan with a five-year horizon and an annual research and development program. Both the plan and the program are to be reviewed and revised annually, following consultation with relevant Australian horticultural industries.

While the corporate plan will set out the longer term strategies and policies that the Corporation intends to adopt in order to achieve its objectives, the annual programs will provide yearly operational schedules for the Corporation by specifying and describing the projects to be carried out, or that may be considered for funding, in the coming year. The annual programs will also provide cost estimates of each project as well as the total anticipated expenditure of the Corporation for the year. Apart from its corporate and operational planning provisions, the Bill contains a number of accountability requirements which are designed to further ensure that the Corporation will carry out its operations in a business-like manner. These requirements are covered in part III, division 4 of the Bill.

The Bill's annual report and accountability to industry provisions are the same as those outlined in my second reading speech for the Australian Horticultural Corporation Bill. The horticultural industries, which have considerable scope to develop their full potential, will be assisted in realising this by a well-organised infrastructure for horticultural research and development. The activities of this Corporation will make significant complementary contributions to those of the other two bodies being established.
I commend the Bill to honourable members. I now present the explanatory memorandum to the House.
Debate (on motion by Mr Miles) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Barry Jones, for Mr Kerin, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jones The Hon B.O.

TALKER.NAME: Mr BARRY JONES
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Science and Small Business)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

The purpose of the Bill is to provide for the establishment of a Horticultural Policy Council as part of the package of measures outlined in my second reading speech for the Australian Horticultural Corporation Bill 1987. The Government perceives that there is a need to bring together representatives of the widely dispersed, fragmented and diverse horticultural sector into a single body with capacity to present to Government a total sectoral perspective on policy issues. That body, the Council, will be able thoroughly to research and examine issues and areas of concern to the sector. I turn now to the specific provisions of the Bill.
Objects, Functions and Powers

The objects, functions and powers are set out in part II of the Bill. The object of the Council is to facilitate development of policy through co-ordinated participation of the horticultural sector in the policy formulation process. The Bill provides the Council with powers necessary to perform its function, which in the main are: to examine, on its own initiative, issues affecting the horticultural sector and report to the Minister; to examine matters relevant to horticulture referred to it by the Minister; and to develop recommendations, guidelines and plans for measures designed to safeguard or further the interests of horticulture.
Organisational Structure

Part III of the Bill provides the composition of the Council. Its membership of 15 will consist of an independent chairperson, five members representing horticultural growers and producers, two members representing processors, one member representing persons engaged in horticultural marketing, two members representing employees, two members representing the Australian Agricultural Council and the chairperson of the Australian Horticultural Corporation and the Horticultural Research and development Corporation respectively. It should take some time to read the minutes. All members will be appointed by the Minister, but members, other than the Council's chairperson and the chairpersons of the two corporations, will be nominated for appointment by relevant bodies, which will be prescribed by regulation.

Also, by regulation, the Bill enables the number and composition of the Council's membership to be varied. This provision has been included so that changing circumstances in the organisational structure of the horticultural sector may be reflected in the representation on the Council as and when the need arises. I should also mention that it will be the Government's policy for variation to be made only after consultation with the Council. The Minister believes-I have heard it from his own lips many times-that it will be essential to keep the Council to a manageable size, and this will be borne in mind in any consideration to vary the Council's membership.

Part IV of the Bill provides the Council with the power and scope to establish and abolish executive or other committees and working groups. With regard to committees, it is intended that they be established to consider specific issues or areas of concern. The composition of such committees may be made up entirely of Council members or partly of members and other persons.

A working group established by the Council may consist entirely of persons other than Council members, or may be composed of Council members and other persons but they must be human beings. Membership of a working group would, in general, be based on expertise rather than representation and it would be expected that the issues being examined by a working group would have a high degree of technical content. The consultancy provisions of part V of the Bill complement the provisions for committees and working groups of the Council. They enable the Council to engage experts who may work on their own or be part of a committee or working group. It will be up to the Council to determine the terms and conditions under which consultants may be engaged.
Administrative Arrangements

Part V of the Bill also makes provision for the Council to be staffed by a permanent secretariat. Staff of the Department of Primary Industries and Energy will fulfil this function. The Government is providing $1.9m to cover the Council's costs over five years. Continuation and subsequent funding of the Council will be reviewed in the fifth year of its operation.

The Bill makes annual report provisions consistent with those applied to other such Commonwealth statutory bodies. To this end, the Bill specifies that the Council is to prepare and submit an annual report each year to the Minister for tabling in the Parliament. The Government considers that the Horticultural Policy Council will provide an important link between industry and the Government in the development of national policies relevant to the horticultural sector. I commend the Bill to honourable members and I now present the explanatory memorandum to this Bill.
Debate (on motion by Mr Miles) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Barry Jones, for Mr Kerin, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jones The Hon B.O.

TALKER.NAME: Mr BARRY JONES
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Science and Small Business)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

The purposes of this Bill and three related Bills-namely, the Horticultural Levy Collection Bill 1987, the Horticultural Export Charge Bill 1987 and the Horticultural Export Charge Collection Bill 1987-are to provide for the imposition and collection of levies on horticultural products produced and sold in Australia and for charges on exports of horticultural products. They provide the means of financing, in the longer term, the activities of the Australian Horticultural Corporation and, apart from Commonwealth matching moneys, the Horticultural Research and Development Corporation.

As the Australian Horticultural Corporation's role will include the servicing of the apple and pear growing industry, the current levies on its products will be imposed and collected under the new levy Bills; and the existing apple and pear levy legislation will be repealed. The operative rates of levy for apples and pears will be set by regulation, while the rates for other horticultural products will be included in regulations as respective horticultural industries decide to participate in the activities of either or both corporations and agree on levy arrangements to help finance marketing and research activities. Levy will be payable by the producer of a horticultural product which is covered by the appropriate regulations while the export charge is to be payable by the owner of the product at the time of export. Provision has been made in the levy and export charge Bills for determination of maximum rates of levy and charge. The maximum rates do, of course, vary from product to product.

In order to limit administrative costs or for policy reasons, certain exemptions from levy will be permitted under regulations; for example, these may be in situations where sales by individual growers are relatively small or where small volumes of horticultural products are retailed direct by growers at the orchard gate or, in relation to products used directly by the grower for juicing or processing purposes, if the relevant annual quantities do not exceed a maximum level as set down in regulations, possibly in marginal seats. DEBATE.TITLE: EGG INDUSTRY RESEARCH (HEN QUOTA) LEVY AMENDMENT BILL 1987

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Barry Jones, for Mr Kerin, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jones The Hon B.O.

TALKER.NAME: Mr BARRY JONES
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Science and Small Business)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

The purpose of this Bill is to amend the Egg Industry Research (Hen Quota) Levy Act 1987 so as to clarify the incidence of the Levy imposed by that Act and collected under an associated Levy Collection Act. The amendments sought stem from advice received by the Government before the levy legislation in question had completed its passage during the last sittings. Plans for incorporating the amendments at that stage were, however, frustrated by the dissolution of the Parliament.

The levy imposed by the levy Act is paid by egg producers to support research programs financed jointly by industry and government. It is levied on hen quotas held by egg producers under State or Territory licences, that is, on the number of laying hens a producer is entitled to keep. As a matter of convenience and economy, collection of the levy in the States is undertaken on behalf of the Commonwealth by State egg boards.

When the levy legislation was awaiting debate in the Senate, after being passed by the House of Representatives, advice was received from industry that the provisions defining the application of the levy did not appear to cater for some variations in State hen quota practices. Examination of these practices against the relevant provisions confirmed that there was room for doubt as to the adequacy of the provisions concerned. Amendments to remedy this shortcoming were drafted for introduction during the debate in the Senate, but in the event, this course could not be followed. Senate debate on the levy legislation was brought on when the autumn sittings were all but ended and the House had already concluded its legislative business. This meant that if the amendment process were initiated at that time, it could not be completed before the dissolution of the Parliament and the legislation imposing the levy would lapse. As the arrangements embodied in the levy legislation depended on the levy commencing on 1 July 1987, significant problems would have resulted if no levy mechanism was in place by that date. Accordingly, it was decided to seek passage of the legislation as it stood and to pursue amendment of the Levy Act in the Budget sittings.

All State authorities concerned with collection of the levy on the Commonwealth's behalf were informed of the intention to amend the Levy Act and of the nature of the proposed amendments. This has enabled levy collection to proceed on the basis to be confirmed by the amendments.

Against this background, I will now explain the genesis and intent of the amendments contained in the Bill. When the levy Act was being framed, the definition of the term `hen quota licence', which largely governs the incidence of the levy, was formulated on the premise that State licences issued to egg producers in all cases specify a hen quota which is the maximum number of laying hens that may be kept. This formulation was adopted after examination of relevant State legislation. It has come to notice, however, that because of the varying ways in which individual States express and notify hen keeping entitlements in actual practice, the definition in question is-at least on a narrow interpretation-at variance with administrative procedures followed in some States.

In order to remove any doubts as to how the levy should apply, the proposed amendments will alter the definition of the term `hen quota licence', add a definition of `hen quota' and make appropriate changes to all provisions of the levy Act where these expressions occur. The effect of these alterations will be to establish clearly that the levy applies to operative hen quotas-that is, actual hen keeping entitlements-irrespective of how or where these are specified by the States under their administrative procedures.

The levy was applied from 1 July 1987 with first payments due on 1 September 1987. As I mentioned earlier, by virtue of prior arrangements with State authorities collecting the levy, the application of the levy has proceeded from the outset on the basis to be confirmed by the amendments. Accordingly, it has been necessary to include a provision making the amendments retrospective to 1 July 1987. It should be stressed, however, that the proposed changes will not impose additional liability on levy payers. Indeed, the position with regard to financial impact is that the amendments will not increase the financing commitments of the Commonwealth or the industry. I commend the Bill to honourable members and present the explanatory memorandum to this Bill.
Debate (on motion by Mr Miles) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Barry Jones, and read a first time.

The Bill makes a number of rather minor amendments to the Patents Act 1952. Most of them are to set up procedures for handling patent applications which relate to nuclear technology. The procedures are needed to ensure compliance with the Nuclear Non-Proliferation (Safeguards) Act 1987-the Safeguards Act-which was passed earlier this year. The new procedures introduced by the Bill relate to patent applications which contain information of a kind referred to in the definition of associated technology in the Safeguards Act. The Safeguards Act provides that associated technology is not to be possessed or communicated without the relevant permit or authority from the Australian Safeguards Office. Under the Safeguards Act, associated technology means a document containing information that is primarily applicable to enrichment of nuclear material, reprocessing of irradiated nuclear material, production of heavy water or nuclear weapons, or nuclear information that is covered by an international agreement and is declared by the Minister to be information for the purposes of this definition. A document is defined to include a photograph, model or other thing from which the information may be obtained. Information publicly available is excluded from the definition.

Clause 4 of the Bill provides for the Commissioner of Patents to refer a specification which appears to contain this kind of information to the Director of Safeguards. If the Director is satisfied that the specification does indeed contain information of the defined type, the Director can send a certificate to that effect to the Commissioner. The Safeguards Office will also check whether the necessary permit and authority to possess and communicate the information had been given. In a case where it emerges that they had not been given, the Director's certificate can include a direction that the patent application is to lapse. The Bill also enables the Commissioner, on the basis of the Director's advice, to take appropriate steps to prohibit or restrict publication of the information contained in a specification. There is provision in clause 4 for restoration of a lapsed application where the applicant's default is subsequently rectified by obtaining the necessary permit and authority. Clause 9 makes various provisions for aggrieved applicants to apply for review by the Administrative Appeals Tribunal of a decision of the Director or Commissioner. Clause 2 imposes an obligation on Safeguards Office staff to observe the usual confidentiality requirements of the Patents Act.

The system set up by the Bill is not particularly complex. The reason its wording runs for a few pages is that the new procedures have to mesh into the provisions of the Patents Act, ensuring particularly that decisions affecting people's rights are taken in a fair and open manner. The number of patent applications which will be affected by the Bill is expected to be small, and the procedures will be handled within existing resources of the Patent Office. Clause 3 makes an amendment consequential on clause 4. Clauses 5, 6 and 7 of the Bill make minor amendments to the Patents Act which are explained in the explanatory memorandum. Clause 7 corrects a drafting error which recently came to light.

The Bill is not momentous, but it sets in place necessary procedures to ensure that the Safeguards Act and the Patents Act operate in a complementary and harmonious fashion. I commend this Bill to the House and present the explanatory memorandum to the Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Morris The Hon P.F.

TALKER.NAME: Mr PETER MORRIS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Resources)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

This Bill makes amendments of an essentially administrative and procedural nature to the Continental Shelf (Living Natural Resources) Act 1984, the Fisheries Act 1952 and the Torres Strait Fisheries Act 1984. I can inform the House that there will be further amendments to the Fisheries Act to give effect in Australian law to the multilateral treaty between the United States and the Pacific Island countries that are members of the Forum Fisheries Agency with respect to the operation of United States tuna boats in the exclusive fishing zones of those countries. The treaty, which was signed on 2 April 1987, will come into force when ratified by 10 Pacific Island countries and the United States.

The Australian fishing industry is undergoing a period of profound change and it pleases me to say that this Government has in considerable measure been keeping in step with those changes. The Government approaches management of our fisheries on a co-operative basis with the fishing industry. We have established the Fishing Industry Policy Council of Australia to provide a forum for government and industry to discuss issues of mutual interest. In the long-established framework of the Australian Fisheries Council, we have strengthened the institutional framework for consulting with the relevant industry sectors about the management of our major fisheries such as northern prawns, tuna, south-east trawl, southern shark and north-west shelf crustaceans. Statutory management plans are already in place with the full co-operation of industry in the two first-mentioned of those fisheries. We are working toward having management plans in place for the others in the near future.

The Government has implemented the fisheries element of the off-shore constitutional settlement with all but two States, with which negotiations are continuing. The off-shore constitutional settlement creates the statutory basis on which the Commonwealth and the States can enter into formal legal arrangements whereby a fishery is managed under a single law, be it Commonwealth or State, from the coast to the outer limit of our fisheries jurisdiction. Arrangements with Queensland in the Torres Strait Protected Zone have been in place now for more than two years. Four arrangements with Tasmania and Victoria have been in place since June 1986. In June 1987, a further 18 arrangements with Queensland, South Australia, Western Australia and Tasmania came into force.

This Bill forms part of a package that includes a Bill to restructure the Commonwealth's involvement in fisheries research and development. This will follow lines essentially similar to those in the Rural Industries Research Act, taking account of the unique institutional factors that make a separate Fisheries Research and Development Act necessary. In 1986-87, the volume of fisheries production was estimated at 152,500 tonnes, with an estimated gross value of $639m. The fishing industry ranks sixth among all Australia's rural industries on a value of production basis. Exports of fishery products have increased from $230m in 1980-81 to an estimated $591m in 1986-87 and have significantly exceeded the value of imports each year during that period. There are more than 9,000 boats in the Australian commercial fishing fleet with an annual consumption of about 240 million litres of diesel fuel. Estimated annual per capita consumption has risen from 6.2 kilograms in 1979-80 to 7.5 kilograms in 1984-85, measured as edible weight. These figures give a general picture of a vigorous fishing industry which is making a very important contribution to the domestic economy and food supplies as well as to foreign exchange earnings.

Against this fairly active domestic background, the provisions of the Bill reflect a wide range of recent administrative experience accumulated by the Australian Fisheries Service and the State fisheries authorities which undertake the day to day administration of the Acts that the Bill amends. The Bill brings the three principal Acts that it amends into line insofar as their administrative provisions are concerned. The Bill shifts the emphasis of the provisions authorising the Minister to make notices for the regulation of the fisheries away from the notices to the prohibitions in them. This will facilitate the preparation of notices containing several prohibitions each requiring separate endorsements of licences.

The Bill strengthens the powers of officers so that they may be better equipped to enforce the three Acts. It does so in accordance with those principles of Commonwealth legal policy that have regard to civil liberties and individuals' rights, taking account of the special circumstances in which the principal Acts are enforced. The difficulties of detecting fisheries offences at sea, far from the nearest land and a magistrate who can issue warrants with reasonable facility, make it necessary to provide fisheries enforcement officers with powers that in other circumstances might seem excessive. The Bill provides powers in this regard that the Government considers to be an acceptable balance between the need for effective enforcement and the protection of civil liberties. The Attorney-General's Department has advised that the Bill conforms with Commonwealth criminal law legal policy.

The Bill provides a basis for ascertaining the state of mind of a director or other agent of a body corporate where it is necessary to do so in legal proceedings for offences for which the Acts provide a penalty for a body corporate. The Bill is of an essentially machinery nature for the better administration of the laws affecting Australia's fisheries and has no financial implications. The explanatory memorandum summarises its clauses, thus making it unnecessary for me to take the time of the House in a detailed explanation of them. I present the explanatory memorandum to this Bill and commend the Bill to honourable members.

DEBATE.TITLE: FISHING INDUSTRY RESEARCH AND DEVELOPMENT BILL 1987

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Peter Morris, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Morris The Hon P.F.

TALKER.NAME: Mr PETER MORRIS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Resources)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

This Bill gives effect to the Government's rural industries research policy insofar as the research and development requirements of the fishing industry are concerned. The Bill replaces, but does not repeal, the Fishing Industry Research Act 1969 which has since its commencement provided a total of $28,540,000 to support research for the benefit of the Australian fishing industry.

The Fishing Industry Research Trust Account established by that Act has supported scientific and biological research in many Australian fisheries. It has provided funds for exploratory fishing projects, fishing gear technology studies, education for fishermen and research into the handling and marketing of fish products. The Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation, universities, government agencies, fishing companies and individual fishermen have received funding from the Account to undertake research. The Account has funded a wide range of industry-related projects; for example, experimental longlining for tuna as the basis of Australia's entry into the lucrative Japanese sashimi market, squid jigging off Tasmania and development of a marketing database on the Viatel system which is attracting interest from exporters, Japanese importers and fishermen's co-operatives. Full details of the operations of the Fishing Industry Research Act are set out in the annual reports of the Fishing Industry Research Committee. The Australian fishing industry has, in my view, received important benefits from the operation of the Fishing Industry Research Act that have contributed over time to the welfare of the industry and its place in the national economy. The Bill provides a basis for this to continue under more modern and representative administrative arrangements consistent with the modern legislative framework for rural industries research generally.

The Bill makes two fundamental changes to the basis of determining the amount that the Commonwealth will match by way of appropriation to the Fisheries Research and Development Trust Fund that the Bill establishes. The Commonwealth will match expenditure from approved State funds rather than revenue collected from industry and credited to those funds. And there will be a ceiling to the Commonwealth appropriation to the Trust Fund, equal in any financial year to 1 per cent of the average annual gross value of production by the catching and culturing sectors of the Australian fishing industry during the three preceding financial years, as determined by the Minister. The mechanism for determining the amount of the appropriation will remain much the same as under the existing legislation; that is, the Minister will determine one fund under each State's fisheries law to be an approved fund and specified money in that fund to be approved money.

The Bill requires all those determinations to be tabled in Parliament and provides for their disallowance as if they were regulations. Before making any determination under part III of the Bill in relation to the Trust Fund, the Minister will have regard to the legislative and administrative basis of State Funds and the moneys credited to those funds. The Bill establishes administrative machinery closely resembling that provided by the Rural Industries Research Act. There is to be a Fishing Industry Research and Development Council, which will prepare five-year plans of fisheries research and development and annual programs for giving effect to that plan, for approval by the Minister.

The Council will undertake the decision-making and administrative functions associated with the Trust Fund, employing staff in classifications approved by the Minister for that purpose. The members of the Council appointed by the Minister will comprise an independent chairperson, a government member experienced in formulation of government policy and public administration, and not fewer than three or more than seven members with experience and knowledge of the fishing industry and fisheries research and a high order of general administrative and managerial ability.

The Bill provides for the Minister to appoint members of a Fishing Industry Research and Development Council Selection Committee, comprising an independent chairperson, a member with experience in fisheries administration or management, a member experienced in fisheries research and development, a member nominated by the Australia Fisheries Council and three members nominated by the National Fishing Industry Council. The Selection Committee will, whenever the Minister requests, put forward so many nominations as there are vacancies on the Council, having regard to the mix of skills and abilities that the Bill requires the Council to possess. The Minister may reject any nomination and request the Selection Committee to submit another one. Previous rejection or non-selection is not a barrier to subsequent nomination. I present the explanatory memorandum to this Bill and commend the Bill to honourable members.

TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Employment Services and Youth Affairs and Minister Assisting the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

The Treasurer (Mr Keating), in his Press releases of 11 June, 30 July and 22 December 1986, announced various operating standards which superannuation funds and approved deposit funds (ADFs) will be required to meet in order to be eligible for relevant taxation concessions. These standards were established following consultations with various interested groups and against the background of the Government's concern to ensure that superannuation arrangements are directed at meeting genuine retirement needs and that members' entitlements are protected.

The Treasurer also referred in his June 1986 statement to the Government's decision to establish a new body called the Insurance and Superannuation Commission to be headed by a new statutory officer. The Commission would bring together the existing Offices of Insurance Commissioner, Life Insurance Commissioner and Australian Government Actuary as well as the proposed office relating to occupational superannuation. The three Bills now before the House, namely, the Occupational Superannuation Standards Bill 1987, the Insurance and Superannuation Commissioner Bill 1987, and the Insurance and Superannuation Commissioner (Consequential Provisions) Bill 1987, give effect to these announcements.

The Occupational Superannuation Standards Bill 1987 establishes the conditions and the supervisory requirements which superannuation funds and ADFs must meet in order to be eligible for concessional taxation treatment under the Income Tax Assessment Act. The Bill provides that these supervisory functions are to be performed by a newly created office-the Insurance and Superannuation Commissioner. The purpose of the Insurance and Superannuation Commissioner Bill 1987 is to create the position of Insurance and Superannuation Commission and thereby establish an Insurance and Superannuation Commission.

The basic objective of the Government's decision to establish such a Commission is to achieve improved efficiency and co-ordination through the integration of the Commonwealth's various insurance, superannuation and actuarial functions. It is also seen as better reflecting the growing importance of the insurance and superannuation industries in the national economy. This objective is reflected in the Bills before us which, rather than adding, as originally envisaged, two additional statutory positions to those already existing, establish the new senior statutory position of Insurance and Superannuation Commissioner and remove the statutory positions of Life Insurance Commissioner and Insurance Commissioner. The earlier proposed statutory office of Occupational Superannuation Commissioner is also not being established. The purpose of the Insurance and Superannuation Commissioner (Consequential Provisions) Bill 1987 is therefore to amend the Life Insurance Act 1945, the Insurance Act 1973 and other insurance legislation to remove the statutory positions of Life Insurance Commissioner and Insurance Commissioner and place their statutory responsibilities in the hands of the new Insurance and Superannuation Commissioner.

The new arrangements will not remove the legislative and institutional distinctions embodied in the Insurance Act 1973 and the Life Insurance Act 1945. These Acts will remain in force, and the specialist nature of the two industries will also be reflected in the management structure of the new Commission. Thus, the former positions of Insurance Commissioner and Life Insurance Commissioner will be replaced by positions of Deputy Commissioner (General Insurance) and Deputy Commissioner (Life Insurance) in the new Insurance and Superannuation Commission, with equivalent status under the Public Service Act. The proposed legislation allows the Insurance and Superannuation Commissioner to delegate to these officers all the powers necessary for them efficiently to administer the specialist legislation. Similar arrangements will apply in the occupational superannuation area with the creation of the position of Deputy Commissioner (Occupational Superannuation).

The Insurance Commissioner and recently retired Life Insurance Commissioner have fully supported and encouraged the Government to adopt the change in approach. They have done so in recognition of the benefits to be derived from the greater integration of the various functions and the difficulties in achieving that objective which could arise from maintaining a number of specific statutory offices. The Government will, of course, ensure that the conditions on which the Insurance Commissioner were appointed will be fully protected.

The status and efficiency of the insurance and superannuation regulatory bodies will be significantly enhanced by the greater administrative and management autonomy, as well as the policy responsibilities which it is intended will reside with the Insurance and Superannuation Commission. The integration of policy responsibilities with the regulatory and industry liaison functions of the Commission will also provide the insurance and superannuation industries with a focal point for discussing matters of concern and should ensure that industry issues are given specialist and co-ordinated attention. The office of the Australian Government Actuary will form part of the Insurance and Superannuation Commission, but the professional independence of the actuarial provided by that Office will, of course, be fully maintained.

I would like now to outline the particular provisions of the Occupational Superannuation Standards Bill 1987. This Bill incorporates provisions to give effect to the handover to the Insurance and Superannuation Commissioner of the supervision of those non-revenue superannuation requirements currently supervised by the Commissioner of Taxation. In essence, the Bill provides that, where the trustees of a superannuation fund or approved deposit fund provide to the Insurance and Superannuation Commissioner certain information on the operation of the fund, together with certificates as prescribed, the Commissioner will notify the trustees of the fund as to whether the Commissioner is satisfied that the Fund has met the relevant standards and requirements for the purpose of establishing eligibility for concessional taxation treatment. Particulars of the Commissioner's notification are to be forwarded to the Commissioner of Taxation.

In brief, these standards, which are to be prescribed in regulations under the Bill, provide for improved vesting of benefits arising from both employee and employer contributions, improved preservation requirements and measures to ensure greater member involvement in the control of superannuation funds and improved security of members' benefits. Funds will also need to comply with the existing requirements of the Income Tax Assessment Act. Pending the passage of legislation expected to be introduced later this year to amend that Act and to relocate those provisions as requirements imposed under the Occupational Superannuation Standards Bill. Implementation of the new standards, most of which commenced to operate from 1 July 1986, represents an important step in ensuring that taxation concessions made available to superannuation funds are directed towards the provision of genuine retirement benefits. To this end, the Occupational Superannuation Standards Bill is an important element in the Government's overall retirement incomes policy.

In developing the legislation, the Government has been anxious to establish a regulatory system incorporating the principle of self-assessment. The arrangements which I have outlined place the onus on trustees to ensure that funds satisfy the operating standards and minimise the degree of interference in the operations of those funds. This minimal supervisory approach is supported by the measures already outlined to provide greater member representation on the boards of trustees and for a greater degree of audit and disclosure of information to members on the operation of the funds. At the same time, it is necessary, in the public interest, to provide the Commissioner with powers to enable more detailed checking of the operations of a fund to test its compliance with the standards. Accordingly, the Bill provides that the Commissioner may, from time to time, require a fund to produce documents for purposes of undertaking routine checks and for initiating appropriate inquiries where there is reason to suspect that there may be non-compliance with the operating standards.

The Commissioner is also to be given the power to revise any notification as to compliance or non-compliance that may have been provided if, on the examination of further material, the Commissioner is satisfied that the notification should be revised. As well, discretionary powers are provided to the Commissioner to treat funds as complying with the requirements in special circumstances where the standards have not been satisfied. The Bill also requires that a statement of reasons be included in any notice of non-compliance the Commissioner might provide and that decisions to notify non-compliance be reviewable. In this regard the appeals provisions in the Bill follow essentially the same pattern as the established appeals machinery in the legislation relating to supervision of the general and life insurance industries.

Under the Bill, where a trustee of a superannuation fund requests that a reviewable decision be reconsidered, the Commissioner will have a maximum period of 21 days within which to confirm, revoke or vary a decision. The provisions will also ensure that upon expiration of that 21-day period, or earlier if the decision is confirmed or varied before then. The trustee will have a period of 28 days within which to apply to have the matter placed before the Administrative Appeals Tribunal if the trustee remains dissatisfied with the Commissioner's decision. Thus the provisions will ensure that an administrator cannot impede the commencement of appeal proceedings through delay in reconsidering a decision.

The standards reflect principles that are well understood in the industry generally and the requirements represent little more than those which should in any case be observed by well-managed superannuation funds. In formulating the standards, the Government took into account the views expressed by a number of bodies on the recommendations in the final report of the task force on occupational superannuation, tabled in May 1983, and on the draft standards released in December 1985 for public comment. The groups which provided advice include the Life Insurance Federation of Australia, the Association of Superannuation Funds of Australia and the Institute of Actuaries of Australia. Consultations with the key industry bodies are continuing as part of the process of drafting detailed regulations to reflect the standards.

The Government believes that there are clear advantages for both industry and government in seeking to have the detailed standards reflected in regulations rather than in the Bill itself. This approach is consistent with that taken in relation to other supervisory legislation, including in respect of the life insurance and general insurance industries, where highly technical administration is involved. More particularly, it recognises that there is considerable complexity in drafting provisions that will take full account of the diverse range of industry practices in circumstances where that industry is subject to rapid change.

In the Government's view, the formulation of the detailed standards in regulations will provide a reasonable and desirable measure of flexibility to allow the standards to be administered in a way that will facilitate maximum co-operation between industry and government in placing the supervisory arrangements in this area on a sound footing. At the same time, the approach will limit the extent to which discretions are placed in the hands of those administering the standards and will, of course, allow parliamentary scrutiny of the standards when the regulations are tabled. I note that this approach has widespread industry support and in this context the Government wishes to acknowledge and endorse the supportive views expressed to the Treasurer by the President of the Institute of Actuaries in his letter of 24 July 1987.

While the Government recognises the considerable size of the administrative task involved in implementing the standards, particularly given that well over 200,000 funds are involved, it is determined that this will not lead to any major growth in staff numbers. The Government estimates that a total staff of 77 will be needed to perform this work and that most of the required staffing resources, equivalent to 66 positions, will be provided by offsets in respect of existing positions concerned with superannuation functions in the Australian Taxation Office. Thus the significant increase in administrative work load will not involve more than the creation of 11 new positions. As previously foreshadowed, the Bill provides for the levying on superannuation funds and approved deposit funds of a prescribed annual fee which will be aimed at recovering the normal costs of supervisory operations. It is intended to set such fee at $30 for returns lodged in the current financial year.

The Bill is generally to come into operation on a date to be fixed by proclamation, but earlier dates have been provided for in relation to two matters. First, regulations made for the purpose of relocating to this Act some of the existing provisions in the tax Act applicable to ADFs are to come into operation on 1 July 1986. Second, the Bill provides that regulations to give effect to the standards announced in the Treasurer's Press statements of 11 June, 30 July and 22 December 1986 may be made with dates of effect foreshadowed in those announcements.

The Government does not see any sound case for deferring implementation of any of the standards as has been suggested by some people. Clearly, such deferral would not be in the interests of superannuation beneficiaries and would set aside the important advances that have already been made towards ensuring that employees, as well as employers and other relevant interests, have an adequate input into the management and operational policies of superannuation funds. It would also run counter to the Government's concerns that superannuation arrangements justify the relatively high levels of taxation concessions directed to that area. The Government remains firm, therefore, in its resolve to implement all of the announced standards without delay so that the role of superannuation funds will be more closely targeted towards meeting the community's retirement needs. Finally, it should be noted that this legislation is not intended to set aside the recourse that members of a fund have by way of normal trustee law. The legislation will also not apply to public sector schemes. However, it remains the Government's intention that public sector schemes comply with similar standards to those applying to funds in the private sector. To that end the Government will be undertaking an examination of funds covering its own employees and where necessary appropriate adjustments will be made. Discussions will also be sought with the governments of the States and the Northern Territory to seek their co-operation in adopting similar standards in respect of funds covering their own employees. I commend the Bill to the House and present the related explanatory memorandum.

The person appointed is not to hold office beyond the age of 65 and is to be paid remuneration as determined by the Remuneration Tribunal.

The Bill contains provisions to guard against conflict of interest. In the May economic statement, the Government foreshadowed its preparedness to sell its interest in the Primary Industry Bank of Australia (PIBA). The Commonwealth, along with all the shareholders in PIBA, subsequently accepted an offer from the Rural and Industries Bank of Western Australia (R and I) to acquire all of the shares in PIBA. The sale of PIBA was completed on 30 June 1987 and resulted in revenue to the Commonwealth of $2.5m. PIBA was established in 1978 under the provisions of the Primary Industry Bank Act 1977 specifically to provide long term funding to the rural sector through a refinance facility. Prior to the acquisition of PIBA by the R and I Bank, the Commonwealth had a 12.5 per cent shareholding and the four major trading banks, and a consortium of the four State banks, each had 17.5 per cent of the shares.

The deregulation of the financial system resulted in there no longer being a need for direct Commonwealth involvement in PIBA. Also, the multiple ownership of PIBA by a consortium of banks and the Commonwealth was proving unwieldy at that stage of PIBA's development. In selling its interest in PIBA, however, the Commonwealth has sought to ensure that the rural sector would not be disadvantaged in its access to banking services previously provided by PIBA and that the rural sector would continue to have a voice on the PIBA board. Following its sale to the R and I Bank, PIBA is now in a position to build upon the valuable service it has provided to the rural sector in the past. In particular, opportunities for accelerated growth and the development of new financial services by PIBA are expected to arise. This will be of particular benefit to farmers given that PIBA's prime commitment will continue to be towards meeting the funding requirements of the rural sector. PIBA was granted a banking authority under section 9 of the Banking Act on 30 June 1987 and as a result the Primary Industry Bank Act 1977 is now redundant. The purpose of this Bill is to seek its repeal and to make certain consequential amendments to the Banking Act 1959. Accordingly, clause 3 of the Bill provides for the repeal of the Primary Industry Bank Act 1977.

Clause 4 of the Bill contains certain consequential amendments to the Banking Act 1959. The effect of these amendments will be to ensure that the provisions of the Banking Act 1959 apply to PIBA in the same way as they apply to all other trading banks. That treatment is now appropriate following the granting to PIBA of a banking authority under section 9 of the Banking Act. I commend the Bill to the House. In doing so, I present the explanatory memorandum to this Bill.
