TALK.START.PARA: —Before the debate is resumed on the Privacy Bill 1986, I remind the House that it has been agreed that a general debate be allowed covering this Bill and the Privacy (Consequential Amendments) Bill 1986.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lamb Mr A.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before the debate was interrupted yesterday, I was illustrating the very clear distinction between those who were political opportunists on this matter in this debate and those who had very genuine and professional concerns within the community and expressed those concerns quite adequately and competently. I chastised the Opposition rather heavily yesterday but because we do not have any of the Australian Democrats in this chamber they escaped any criticism.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to take up the debate again at that point. I refer to a full page advertisement which appeared on the back of the Australian Society in July this year as part of the election campaign. The article sets out the Australian Democrats' performance, their concerns and why they claim that the democratic future of the people depends on them. Not once in that advertisement is there any reference to the Australia Card, the need for privacy Bills or a data protection agency. This is another example of hypocrisy from a party represented in another place. The Australian Democrats believe that this is an issue of importance, yet it was not debated; they did not take up the cudgels themselves. They did not have the honesty to admit that the Government did go to the people and was prepared to debate this matter and that they did not take it up. So all members of the Opposition in both Houses of Parliament stand guilty of not raising what they now raise in a most cheap, base and opportunistic way.

Let me return to the aims and objectives of the Privacy Bill before us. The Privacy Bill provides our citizens with a level of privacy protection that is consistent with efficient government administration. It contains a comprehensive set of rules meshing with other legislation dealing with information about individuals held by government. It is a companion of other measures designed to protect any abuse of the Australia Card system, such as the Data Protection Agency (DPA). It follows the example of similar countries such as the United States of America and Canada which have introduced privacy protection legislation. We have, in fact, drawn heavily on guidelines established through the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development and the Australian Law Reform Commissioner, Mr Justice Michael Kirby, who developed the final form of the guidelines before us. Those principles need to be restated. They are simply these: the Agency must have a lawful purpose to collect any information; that information must relate to the Agency's work; the Agency must advise and inform the citizen concerned of the collection and purpose of the information; the information must be stored securely; and there must be restricted access.

The honourable member for Flinders (Mr Reith), in his tirade yesterday, attacked this privacy legislation for being weak and yet those principles were set out on pages 74 and 75 of the report of the Joint Select Committee on an Australia Card. I suggest that the honourable member for Flinders must, indeed, be casting a slur on members of his own Party who supported those principles because he is decrying the legislation as weak. It was nothing more than an opportunistic outburst. Any breach will be deemed as interference with privacy and will be handled by the Data Protection Agency. As I said, those agencies will operate under the guidance of the DPA.

I think people need to know the consequences of the defeat of this Bill. We need this sort of legislation, not only because of the Australia Card, but also because separate data banks and agencies are already holding information about citizens and the citizen's privacy should be protected against abuse. This Bill will do just that. Whether or not an Australia Card is in place, this Bill is necessary and should be supported. I strongly believe that this sort of legislation in an appropriate form should be extended to the private sector. There are far more abuses of data banks held by private concerns, and this goes uncriticised by the Opposition. There is no suggestion from honourable members opposite that privacy Bills should be extended to that sector. Through the corporations power I would like to see the Government introduce appropriate legislation to ensure privacy in private data banks. I will be a little cynical at this point and say that if the Australia Card were privatised tomorrow, honourable members opposite would have no criticism of it. They would support it. That is the sort of cynical, opportunistic attitude they have.
This legislation is a national first to protect the privacy of records. It provides a model which could be extended to the private sector. I commend the legislation to the House.

TALK.START.PARA: — Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McGauran Mr P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member for Streeton (Mr Lamb), who has just spoken in the debate, prides himself on the purity of his ideology and the fineness of his ideals. Quite frankly, he wears his heart on his sleeve. I admire that and have a great deal of respect for the honourable member for Streeton. But he cannot have it both ways. He can attack the Australian Democrats for their cheap, opportunistic advertisements which never mention anything about the Australia Card or privacy provisions. I thoroughly agree, but anybody who believes that the Democrats are anything other than political opportunists really needs a base lesson in politics.

SPEECH.PARA: But the honourable member for Streeton does not come to this debate with clean hands. How many times during the campaign did he-or for that matter any of his colleagues-raise the issue of the Australia Card? He is on record as opposing the Australia Card. He cannot wear his heart on his sleeve and sell out his principles time and again as is required of people as soon as they sign the Caucus pledge which prevents them ever disagreeing with the Government in public or in this chamber, or from crossing the floor. The honourable member has sold his soul. There is no other way of putting it. Of course there is pressure on the conservative side of politics not to break ranks and vote with the other side. But in the final analysis we retain the right to do that. Those opposite do not. They sell themselves down the drain. They did not raise the Australia Card during the campaign; we did.

The only reason we are on the brink of a third rejection of the Australia Card legislation in the Senate and a joint sitting for the Government to ram the legislation through is that we have voted against it. We have voted against it since it was introduced late last year. We have been publicising the Australia Card to the very best of our ability. We are not apologetic in any sense of the word in answering the criticism that the issue was not raised in the election. Heaven knows, we tried as best we could to do so. The honourable member for Flinders (Mr Reith) and the honourable member for Mitchell (Mr Cadman), who is in the chamber, took prominent leads in that effort. The Leader of the National Party (Mr Sinclair) sent out at least eight formal Press releases on the identity card alone during that 3 1/2-week campaign. Indeed, the Land rural newspaper in New South Wales in a recent editorial gave him credit for having been consistently opposed to the ID card. So we, more than anybody else in the community, can claim sincerity in our opposition to the Australia Card.

But I should not be distracted by the contributions of the discredited-sadly-honourable member for Streeton. I will address the substance of the Privacy Bill 1986 and the Privacy (Consequential Amendments) Bill 1986 which are before the House. The Opposition opposes the privacy Bills on two grounds. Firstly, they are linked to the Australia Card. We cannot have one without the other. Secondly, even if these Bills were presented as standing apart and aside from the Australia Card, we would oppose them because they do not go far enough. They do not have strong enough provisions to protect an individual's rights. Moreover, there are no enforcement provisions.

As we examine the privacy Bills the extraordinary thing we find is that the Government says on the one hand that privacy is important enough to set out a number of principles on it, but on the other hand it is not important enough to enforce those principles. This is the most extraordinary, watered-down piece of privacy legislation that could ever have been dreamed up. But that is to be expected, because this legislation has entered this chamber several years after a mammoth investigation into privacy by the Australian Law Reform Commission. That Commission was given in 1976 under a Liberal- National Party coalition a charter to investigate privacy. It reported in 1983. Now in 1987 we get some weak and watered-down legislation far removed from the recommendations of that Commission.

I hasten to add that there has been substantial criticism that the Commission's recommendations were weak enough as it is. These provisions contained in the privacy legislation follow not the substance of the Commission's recommendations, which arguably are weak enough, but merely the form in a generalised fashion. So how the honourable member for Streeton, who prides himself on his civil libertarian expertise, can defend legislation like this, particularly when it is so intertwined with the Australia Card, escapes me.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why do you not move an amendment? You are silent.

—How can we possibly amend legislation which in the first place cannot stand alone? It is so weak and watered down that it cannot be amended. Also, it is linked to the Australia Card, and in no way are we weakening in our resolve to oppose each and every aspect of the Australia Card.

SPEECH.PARA: I have read the second reading speech that the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) made when he introduced the legislation for debate by the House. It is one of the worst-if not the worst-second reading speeches that I have had to read in my 4 1/2 years in this place. It is unclear and lacking in specifics. No one is any the wiser after reading it. I suggest that those people who have an interest in the very important issue of privacy obtain a second reading speech to find just how inadequately the Government has prepared this legislation and how little seriousness the Government demonstrates in its commitment to privacy.

The Government should not underestimate the community's concern about this whole issue of privacy. This issue has come to the fore in a great many Western democratic countries in recent years. As government acquire the ability to obtain more and more information about individuals or groups on massive and sophisticated computers, the more we start to worry. A great many people are becoming concerned by the ever-expanding process of collection of information. At present, as many honourable members would know, privacy is protected to some extent by common law as well as by statutory provisions. I take as examples the law of defamation, the law of passing off and the law of copyright. But that is not enough to truly protect an individual's rights of privacy.

The capacity of modern technology, principally through computers, to accumulate information is disturbing to say the least. What protection does an individual have from dissemination of that information? What remedies does that same individual have for breaches of privacy? The legislation before the House fails to address either of those two fundamental matters. All the legislation does is set out a number of so-called information privacy principles. Unfortunately, the definition of what amounts to privacy is far too weak. For instance, the legislation deals only with the specific issue of collecting and using personal information. It fails to include in a generalised form any definition of privacy. Moreover, the legislation omits any sanctions for breaches of these principles. There are no civil or criminal penalties. I hasten to add that in respect of the Commonwealth public sector, the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission will have the power to investigate and report with recommendations. That will give that interesting little body something more to do if this information is to be passed. I will refrain from giving my view of the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission. Suffice it to say that it will be abolished by the coalition on returning to Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —That says it all.

—As the honourable member for Riverina-Darling said, that says it all. The Government maintains that it is important enough to list the privacy principles, but it is not important enough to enforce them. So why do we have damages for civil actions such as defamation or breach of confidence, but not for breaches of this legislation? The Government cannot possibly argue that the matter is too complex or too difficult to solve and that it is unable to formulate appropriate damages or penalties when already precedents exist in common law and for that matter within statute law. The Bill before the House will have no civil or criminal penalties and therefore will have no real effect. There may be some minimal administrative effects, which may deter some bodies or people from breaches of this legislation, but in the final analysis, it is far too ineffective to be of any substance.

SPEECH.PARA: In my view, it would have been better not to have introduced a privacy Bill at all. It is only a token effort, and if it is passed, it will stultify reform in this area. The Government will proceed no further. It will argue that it does not have to and that it has addressed the major worry of so many people about privacy and the keeping of records and dissemination of that information. In other words, it will trumpet far and wide its commitment to an individual's right to privacy and therefore delude people into thinking that nothing more needs to be done because something has occurred. Nothing of any substance has occurred and it is a cynical exercise by the Government, which has once again pushed aside a troubling political problem which might cause it unpopularity. That is the trade mark of this Government. Whenever a problem arises, either in Parliament, in the media or through some special interest group, it pushes it to one side and either kills it by way of committees or investigations that never amount to anything, or by introducing weak, watered down legislation. That is no way to conduct government.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tell it to the Senate.

—There are interjections from members on Government benches. If this legislation is so important to the Government, why has it delayed so long in introducing it? If the matters of principle are so important, why will it not enforce them? Moreover, why has it not consulted more widely, because a number of groups, not least the Law Council of Australia, argue that these principles are so weak as to be worthless.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government argues that the issue of privacy has been largely settled by this legislation. That is manifestly false. As long as the Government is allowed to get away with wrapping itself in a blanket of complacency, it will proceed unchecked. The legislation is a sham and it demonstrates the Government's total lack of commitment to the individual's right to privacy. What protection is afforded to Australians from the Big Brother under this legislation? Very little if any. We need legislation to safeguard the liberties and reputations of the honest in the community. By establishing the Data Protection Agency to oversee the identification card scheme-that is, the ID card-the Government cements Big Brother in our community.

It is not enough that the Government has introduced ineffective privacy legislation. It is now setting up an ID system and, with it, the looming spectre of Big Brother. As if the problem of governments accumulating information is not bad enough-it is an enormous problem and I do not for a moment suggest that there is an easy solution-we shall now have an ID card system and all that that entails. The ID card system makes a nonsense of any notion of privacy. It would have been hard enough to formulate workable privacy legislation without an ID system, but it will now be impossible. The ID card legislation is called the Australia Card legislation, but who can term it that when it is such an un-Australian concept?

TALK.START.PARA: —It is unpatriotic.

—It is indeed unpatriotic as the honourable member for Mitchell suggests. The Data Protection Agency established under the Australia Card legislation will be charged with administering the privacy safeguards. An ID card register is to be set up under that legislation to contain all the central information, and the Health Insurance Commission has to establish an administering authority for the ID card.

SPEECH.PARA: What Government departments will have access to the authority to be set up by the Health Insurance Commission to oversee the operations of this central Data Protection Agency? It is rather astonishing because there is a huge list of just who may and who may not have access, but suffice it to say that there will be links between Government departments and the authority, and the authority can access information from the Tax Office, Medicare, the Department of Defence, Norfolk Island and the departments that cover the following Acts: Social Security Act 1947, Veterans' Entitlements Act 1986, Veterans' Entitlements (Transitional Provisions and Consequential Amendments) Act 1986, Seamen's War Pensions and Allowances Act 1940, Student Assistance Act 1973 and Migration Act 1958. The list goes on and on but rather than take what little time I have left to me with an exhaustive list, I make the point that this central card register will be accessed by a whole number of Government authorities. Where are the safeguards?

Moreover, where are the safeguards from access by individuals, by some of these famous hackers or other inquiring persons? It is something of a coincidence, but very helpful nonetheless, that yesterday came the news that six young West German computer hackers had broken into the computer network of no less a body than the National Aeronautics and Space Administration (NASA). They have broken into 135 computer centres of NASA, the principal space agency in the world, which has very close and continuing links with the defence establishment of the United States. One can imagine that NASA would have the best protective measures against unlawful access by people.

Moreover, there has been debate in this chamber all week about whether or not the computer landlines supplied by Telecom Australia will be safeguarded. The honourable member for Cowper (Mr Nehl) and the shadow Minister for Health, the honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey), have been leading that fight this week, and we have received unsatisfactory answers to detailed questions about the safety and security of the computer line. The honourable member for O'Connor has now received a written reply from the Minister for Land Transport and Infrastructure Support (Mr Duncan), who represents the Minister for Transport and Communications (Senator Gareth Evans) in this place. My quote from the Minister's reply will send shivers up your spine. He said:
Many people may not be aware that modern communication dedicated data networks are not in fact a physical `your use only' network of data lines.
In other words, they are not single but shared lines. The reply continued:
The various data streams of a number of dedicated users will be multiplexed, or combined, and demultiplexed . . .
You see the jargon that is used, Mr Deputy Speaker. We are moving into the era of Big Brother, and all the gobbledegook that goes with it. It goes on:

. . . demultiplexed as they are moved around the country. Individual dedicated users cannot tap into the data of other dedicated users. Dedicated data systems can still be compromised by someone physically tapping into an exchange or transmission line.

I stress that last sentence. There is a remarkably honest admission by the Minister representing the Minister for Transport and Communications that one cannot secure transmission lines against interception. It will not be easy, but someone with sufficient purpose, experience and skill will be able to do so. I also worry about the use of the central card system. Mr Jan Freese, who was formerly director-general of the Swedish Data Inspection Agency for 12 years-bearing in mind that our system is almost directly modelled on that-resigned six months ago for two reasons. The first was that bureaucrats were plugging into the system for all sorts of information and surveys and, secondly, that other people were using it, and moreover the Government was coming to rely on it.

So we have modelled ourselves on the Swedish system. Mr Jan Freese, who is now Deputy Director of the Confederation of Swedish Industry, has rejected it. He has said that it has become very corrupt and that Big Brother now totally controls their lives. The Swedish ID system which has been in place for 20 years has exploded beyond the original purpose and that is exactly what will happen with our system. Firstly, the purposes for which we need our card will be expanded. Secondly, the information will not be protected.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for his question. The Australian Government is greatly encouraged by the recent improvements in the momentum of talks between the United States of America and the Soviet Union on a possible intermediate-range nuclear forces (INF) agreement. Quite clearly, there is now a definite prospect that the current meeting between Secretary Shultz and Foreign Minister Shevardnadze will reach agreement on the matters which remain outstanding. Certainly, the Australian Government looks forward to the early conclusion of a formal agreement between the two sides for an effectively verifiable dismantling of all INF systems.

ANSWER.PARA: I point out to the honourable gentleman and, indeed, to the House as a whole that two aspects in particular are worthy of note. Firstly, as the honourable gentleman who asked the question would recognise, this agreement, when signed, will be the first agreement signed between the super-powers leading to an actual reduction in numbers and types of nuclear weapons; hence the comment by a Soviet spokesman recently-an accurate statement I believe-that we are seeing history in the making. The second feature, of course, is that the acceptance of the global double zero solution is of special significance to countries in the Asia and Pacific region in that it overcomes the earlier concern that those countries and Australia had that Asia-based missiles would not be part of an agreement.

In addition to progress towards an INF agreement, the Australian Government welcomes the announcement of steps to be taken towards ratification of two existing treaties on nuclear testing-the US-USSR Threshold Test Ban Treaty of 1974 and the Peaceful Nuclear Explosions Treaty of 1976-as steps which include joint verification experiments at test sites in both countries. This is certainly and, I think, properly seen by the two sides as part of a process leading to the ultimate cessation of nuclear testing, an objective which, as the honourable member certainly knows, has been central to Australia's arms control and disarmament policies over the years. Similarly, we welcome the 15 September agreement between the United States and the Soviet Union to establish nuclear risk reduction centres which President Reagan has described as a practical step to reduce risks of conflict that could otherwise result from accidents, miscalculations or misunderstanding.

The Australian Government is encouraged to hope that current progress towards an INF agreement will lead to further balanced and verifiable agreements to reduce other categories of nuclear weapons. Certainly, we will continue to urge the nuclear weapons States to build upon the positive developments arising from the Shultz-Shevardnadze meeting. I had the opportunity of discussing these matters with Secretary Shultz when he was in Australia in June and with Foreign Minister Shevardnadze when he was in Australia in March. I look forward to the opportunity of continuing these discussions with Secretary Shultz in the United States in the early part of next month and I also hope that, in the not too distant future, I will have the opportunity of discussions on these matters with the Soviet Government.

I think it is appropriate, and I am sure that I speak on behalf of both sides of the House, to record the appreciation of the Australian Government for the major effort which has been made by the United States Administration, including Secretary Shultz in particular, and by the Soviet Government in achieving the progress that we have seen to this point.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Science and Small Business. In the last few days there have been numerous media reports about the Commission for the Future, the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation (CSIRO) and the greenhouse effect. I ask: Why is the Commission for the Future involved in these activities and, specifically, what have these activities been?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Jones The Hon B.O.

TALK.START.PARA: —The CSIRO approached the Commission for the Future as the appropriate body to draw together major sectors in the community so that they could be briefed on scientific evidence about the greenhouse effect. I urge all honourable members who happen to have electoral seats with a coastal border, especially those honourable members from Tasmania, to listen very carefully. The CSIRO recognised the Commission's expertise in this area and, as a result of the collaboration, the Greenhouse Project: Planning for Climate Change emerged. What they are attempting to do is to develop a better understanding of climate change at a local and regional level to assess the likely impacts of the changes, to plan for the minimisation of adverse effects and maximisation of any likely benefits and to identify policy changes to avert the adverse long term effects of the greenhouse effect. There will be a series of workshops organised, both in 1987 and in 1988, with the involvement and support of a number of groups such as primary industry, manufacturing and construction, service industries, public works and services, water industry, resources and energy, government policy and law, conservation and environment and education and the media.

ANSWER.PARA: At the first meeting this week the major issue that emerged was a call for more research on climatic change at a local and regional level, so that the various sectors could plan in detail for those climatic changes. For example, the manufacturing group commented on the likely change of population distribution following climate changes and the impact this would have on domestic and overseas markets and the established distribution systems for products. There was discussion also on the need for the insurance industry to focus, for example, on preventive actions to reduce the risks to buildings resulting from climate changes. Concern about the coasts, in particular coastal erosion, and associated drainage and sewerage plants was common to a number of groups.

It is very important that we get the concept of the greenhouse effect in context. It is a classic illustration of how if we are only prepared to plan five years, 10 years, 15 years or 20 years down the track all the dangers that are feared can be avoided. Of course, we have to take both a national responsibility and an individual responsibility because it is the pattern of energy usage of all of us as individuals, members of families and groups and so on, that will determine the outcome, not just in this country alone, of course. I think this is a matter on which we need to have a much higher degree of international interaction.

The fundamental question is whether this is another factor that we can just leave to the market to work out or whether we need to take some preventive measures to ensure that there is a much higher level of public understanding of what can, potentially, be the greatest environment disaster of all time.

—I refer the Minister for Industrial Relations to the national wage decision earlier this year which established new wage fixation principles and ask: Can the Minister advise the House what developments have occurred regarding implementation of the second tier increases provided for in those principles?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Willis The Hon R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for Hinkler for his maiden question and wish him a long stay in this House. The matter raised by the honourable member is indeed quite important. As he said, the wage principles established by the Commission in March this year provided for two avenues of wage increase. The first tier wage increase is a general wage increase and the second tier wage increase is one that can be obtained through various principles but on an award by award or enterprise by enterprise basis. In the proceeds of establishing that two-tier system the Commission established a new restructuring and efficiency principle which provided for second tier increases to be obtained by measures to improve efficiency such changes as to restrictive work and management practices, changing patterns of work and, also, increasing the flexibility of the work force through a reduction of demarcation barriers and advanced multi-skilling providing for training and retraining.

ANSWER.PARA: The Government very much welcomed the implementation of this principle by the Commission because it was one which we strongly supported and which we believed gave impetus to our drive for the removal of restrictive work and management practices and an increase in productivity in the nation. For the first time in our history we now have a wage system substantially based on productivity improvement. Although it is six months since that national wage decision, only a small proportion of wage and salary earners have obtained a second tier increase-about 460,000 or 8 per cent of wage and salary earners have obtained that second tier increase. That proportion is low because the system requires substantial negotiations to be undertaken before the offsets required under the restructuring and efficiency principle can be obtained.

The major industries where the second tier increases have so far been obtained are: metals, chemicals, food processing, vehicles, building, timber and also some areas of Australian Government employment-Telecom Australia, Australia Post and the Commonwealth Bank. In those three areas of Australian Government employment there has been a 100 per cent trade-off. In other words, there is no cost to the Government as a result of those increases because they have been more than offset by the trade-offs obtained. The procedures used in the trade-offs obtained are variable, but in general they have been very pleasing. For instance, in the metals industry over 460 enterprise agreements have been ratified so far by the Commission. Hundreds more are being considered. Also there have been a number of significant changes to the metal industry award.

Across all industries in which second tier increases so far have been given, the major changes are: the elimination of some allowances or practices; increases in the spread of hours in which people can be employed; reductions in the Christmas close down; increases in flexibility in rostered days off; actions to reduce job demarcation; provision for multi-skilling; the removal of training restrictions, for example, the provision of adult apprenticeships; reduction in manning; removal of one in, all in overtime arrangements; payment of wages by electronic funds transfer, instead of in cash; restructuring awards to provide for the more flexible use of the work force; the establishment of dispute settling procedures and removal of restrictions on part time employment. Those are the more important of the changes that have been made. It is by no means an exhaustive list.

I think honourable members can see from that list that very dramatic changes are taking place in our work places today, and that because of the action initiated by the Government last year in respect of restrictive work and management practices and because of the enormous impetus that that has received from the wage fixing system, we now have in place an enormous amount of activity to make our work places more productive and efficient. We are now able to remove productivity-inhibiting practices which have applied for a long time. That will mean a significant boost to national productivity. The Opposition has been implying this week that the system is failing because there is not a big productivity increase scheduled for 1987-88, but what it must realise is that this system will be phased in through the course of 1987-88. The real impact will be felt in 1988-89; we will see the full impact of this system when a full year of productivity improvements then applies. There will be a large boost to national productivity in that financial year.

—I address my question to the Minister for Science and Small Business, pursuant to an answer he has just given in respect of the glasshouse effect. Would it not be true that if the world were massively to turn to nuclear energy, there would be a diminution of the glasshouse effect? If that were the case, much of the uranium required would be supplied by Australia, so would not Australia have a moral obligation to provide services to the world for the storage of waste because we have the best technology, geography and geology to do so?

—I thank the honourable member for Kalgoorlie for his question, which is absolutely without notice. I am not sure whether the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy might not be more comfortable with it. This, in fact, is one of the fundamental issues that the world has to look at. There are very serious problems, in Europe, particularly, with the effect of acid rain and other phenomena as well which are clearly associated with the conventional use of coal technology and so on. On the other hand, I suppose we would have to say that in Australia we are not terribly keen at this stage on looking towards even more rapid reductions in the world consumption of coal.
—Chernobyl was not too good either, was it?

—Chernobyl was not exactly a great success. There is a fundamental question which has to be resolved in the long term about the comparative merits of the nuclear alternative as against the conventional use of coal and as against the development of other alternative strategies such as the more efficient use of energy; in other words, getting a higher degree of deliverable energy out of new technologies that are being developed. For example, I will mention something that the honourable member for Kalgoorlie I know has a very keen interest in, something that is quite new. In the course of the week, I had a visit from Professor Herman Branover of the Beersheba University-an area with which people who see the film The Lighthorsemen will become familiar. He is doing remarkable work on following up a procedure that really has been understood for about 120 years but not yet developed, and that is the generation of electricity in high volume by getting molten lead and turning it through a very elaborate series of pipes.
—How do you melt the lead, Barry?

—With coal. The molten lead is aerated with molten globules then proceeds through a pipe at high speed. On either side are the poles of a magnet. That movement then generates electricity in an extraordinarily efficient way. Professor Branover says that he is getting a fuel efficiency in excess of 40 per cent.
—Oh, of 40 per cent!

—We are having some enlightenment from the honourable member for Gippsland on the subject. We are not getting a very high level of intellectual efficiency from that corner of the chamber ending with the honourable member for Gilmore. That process can cause a dramatic reduction in coal use, but may cause a very dramatic increase in the international market for lead. So in every area, as I have been saying quite a lot lately, the implications of the development of super-conducting materials can be tremendous for the rare earths industry-the development of rare earths both here and in China-but on the other hand it is very likely to have negative effects on the coal industry. So in a way all these issues are part of one continuum and all have to be looked at.
—There is a universal Occam's razor.
—The Prime Minister is absolutely correct, as usual. I cannot top that.

—Is the Prime Minister aware of a statement made yesterday by a South African Congress of Trade Union head, Aaron Pemba, who is attending an Australian Council of Trade Unions conference in Brisbane in which he issued a blunt death threat to Australian sports people who venture into South Africa? In regard to the latter part of the question, no, I will not ask the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs to take such steps. Madam Speaker, if you will excuse me I would like to take the opportunity to make a couple of comments on the implications of the question. I deplore the concept of violence, whether it is by white or black, and therefore any suggestion of violence and threats of death, whether made by a representative of black Africa here or practitioners of violence by white Africans, I deplore. The resolution of the tragedy of South Africa will not be advanced by that sort of talk or those sorts of threats.

ANSWER.PARA: I hope that the good sense of Australian sports men and women will lead them to the conclusion that it would be entirely improper for them to go to South Africa. I hope that they will not make their decision in terms of some assessment about threat to their life and limb but rather on the moral ground that it would be improper to be giving sustenance and support to a regime which is increasingly around the world attracting condemnation. TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy aware of reports in the Northern Territory media that suggest that this Government would support the location of a high level nuclear waste disposal dump in the Northern Territory? Can the Minister explain whether this is the Government's intention?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kerin The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for the Northern Territory for the question; no doubt the honourable member for Kalgoorlie will have interest in it as well. I guess I have always thought that the Northern Territory is about 162,000 people run by an Apex Club but some of my naivety about the Press was dispelled last week when I was in the Territory. I am not sure about the honourable member's ideological fantasies, I do not know him well enough, but I got a good appraisal of Mr Coulter's-he is the Minister for Mines and Energy-and I got an even better appraisal of Mr Alcorta's, whom I am sure the honourable member does not always go along with.

ANSWER.PARA: To take this whole issue and the publicity it got in the Northern Territory Press back to its source, at the meeting of the Australian Minerals and Energy Council in Perth the week before when we were discussing a policy paper `Energy 2000' Mr Coulter from the Northern Territory raised the whole question of further down the nuclear cycle in Australia. He had just been to La Hague in France. Subsequently he gave me a pretty little pamphlet. People there have been heavily into uranium reprocessing gas graphite fuel since 1966. They are moving into light water reactor fuels and breeder fuels. They are constructing now a multipurpose plant. Mr Coulter seems to think this is a pretty good thing for the Northern Territory. In the terms of the debate in the Council I pointed out that as far as the Commonwealth Government was concerned these matters had been covered by our examination of an decisions on the Slatyer report on Nuclear Science and Technology in Australia.

As honourable members will recall, the Government rejected two recommendations of the Slatyer report, recommendations 1 and 9. Recommendation 1 gave the Government its three uranium mine policy. I am sure the honourable member for Kalgoorlie understands the wisdom of that policy-not one mine, not five mines but three. The other part of the policy is no nuclear cycle. That is very much the Government's firm belief. In terms of the further reprocessing, Mr Coulter rejoined that the technology had improved a lot, that smaller reprocessing facilities could be built. I said that if that was so I could get back to him. The Council subsequently noted that fact that if there was any need to update any of the information in the Slatyer report the Commonwealth would communicate that to the States and the Territory. Lo and behold, it was reported in the Northern Territory Press that we were giving the go ahead to further processing down the nuclear fuel cycle.

There is one area where there is some accuracy in the reports and that concerns the repository for Australia's low level waste. Honourable members will be aware that the Slatyer report recommended that Australia should find better ways and means of disposing of its own low level nuclear waste, which is stored in various areas around the country in 44-gallon drums. The Northern Territory Government has indicated that it has an interest in hosting such a facility. All I advised a Press conference-I actually read from the briefing-was that we acknowledge the Northern Territory Government, as indicated, has an interest in hosting such a facility and the Commonwealth Government is awaiting advice that the Northern Territory wishes to develop this important national service. Anything to do with this is the concern of the Northern Territory Government. It does not mean that the Commonwealth Government has taken any decision on it. As it was a matter of some debate at the public level in the Northern Territory with respect to the election for the seat of Barkly, which centres on Tennant Creek, and the subsequent by-election I would have thought that the Northern Territory media understood exactly what I was taking about.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister for Administrative Services: What is being done to upgrade the equipment of the Bureau of Meteorology, and, particularly, to improve its tropical cyclone, bushfire and flood warning services?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: West The Hon S.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —At the outset, I recognise that the answer to this question is of extreme importance to the honourable member for Leichhardt and I recognise his abiding interest in these measures. I inform the House that we as a Government have undertaken to upgrade the Bureau, particularly the severe weather warning capability notification services in northern Australia. We will provide the staff and funds to proceed with this upgrading. The tropical cyclone warning service for northern Australia will be improved by the appointment of cyclone specialists in the tropical cyclone warning centres in Brisbane, Darwin and Perth. These cyclone experts will develop improved tracking and forecasting systems and will help to man the warning centres during periods of cyclone threat. We will also complete the system of remote weatherwatch radar displays. This will give forecasters located in the tropical cyclone warning centres instant access to the weather information portrayed by the radars located along the tropical coastline, particularly of north Queensland. The flood warning system will benefit from the appointment of additional specialists to the flood warning centres in Brisbane, Sydney and Melbourne. It will also benefit from the establishment of flood warning centres in Hobart and Adelaide. Those specialists will assist in the development or improved techniques for forecasting floods and the increased emphasis on the forecasting of flash flood problems.

ANSWER.PARA: Finally, I inform the House that the bushfire warning service will also be improved by the provision of weather experts in the Adelaide, Melbourne, Sydney and Hobart forecast centres. These experts will assist in the preparation of fire warning during the fire season. During the winter months they will conduct research aimed at improving their forecasting capability. Many sections of our society in this very large country are extremely dependent on advance warning of natural calamity. I give my assurance that the Hawke Labor Government is committed to the upgrading of these absolutely vital services, particularly to the people of northern Australia.

The statement that the Minister tabled when this House met this morning was drooling with minutes and all of them cast into doubt the whole question of the capabilities of the successful coastal surveillance contractor. Now, in an answer to a question raised in the House today, the Minister has resurrected the minute; the minute has reappeared. He said:
I have not seen the minute and therefore I am not able to say which one it was.

The Minister said that there was a minute; Senator Evans said that there was not a minute; the Minister said there was not a minute; Senator Evans and the Minister said that there was a minute; and now the Minister has confirmed that there was a minute.

The Opposition has been pressing for months for the Government to come clean on the Coastwatch affair. Naturally, I asked at an early stage of the proceedings what, if anything, was on the record of the police aspects of it . . .

This Minister did not even bother to ask about the security aspects of the contract. The Minister in the other House had no difficulty in asking about that. This Minister was sworn in on 24 July. The matter in issue is the possible embarrassment to the Government.

Robert Amann has had problems with aviation, the variation of specifications/duplication of administration and decision making within that Department has caused him concern.
The minute continues:
This is not, apparently, an uncommon complaint from anybody involved in the bureaucratic machinery in the Department of Aviation.

What on earth was the Minister doing to protect Australia's northern surveillance interests at that time? TALK.START.PARA: —We are speaking now about the Privacy Bill 1986 and the Privacy (Consequential Amendments) Bill 1986. The Opposition has attacked this legislation as if it were an assault on privacy. The Bill actually strengthens privacy and in no way reduces it. Privacy is a right that we all have and all value. A German proverb says, `A hedge between keeps friendships green'. We need to be able to have time on our own and to go about daily life without undue hindrance. That is what this Bill is about. Yet we have members in this House opposing this legislation, ostensibly because it is associated with the Australia Card legislation. We present a Bill to make sure that the activities of Commonwealth agencies do not adversely effect privacy. It partners a Bill which gives governments the same right as any business would demand. A business is able to bring together funds that it receives from people or firms and check them against the funds paid out to people or firms, yet the Opposition wants to hinder the Government from streamlining its own processes by bringing together the dealings of any one Australian in relation to taxation, social security and Medicare, as it did with the Australia Card Bill presented on Wednesday.

SPEECH.PARA: Yesterday, the Opposition opposed Government legislation which makes sure that each of us pays to the Government his or her debt and receives from the Government his or her due. Surely it is a right of any properly run business to pay out no more than its due and to receive proper declared prices for services. Here we have an Opposition which keeps telling the Government that it ought to operate like a properly run business and doing everything that it can to stop that. John Valder, the National President of the Liberal Party, tried to tell the Opposition to operate like a business. He implied that it would not be done unless it tested for assets with pensions and taxed fringe benefits. I add that it will not be done without a capital gains tax. The Liberal Party rejected that, and did everything that it could-not very much, for it is a moribund party weighed down by doctrine and yesterday's strategies-to stop the Government from operating in a business-like way. On Wednesday, with the National Party, the Liberal Party voted against a business-like principle, the Australia Card, which would help Treasury and Finance receive their due and pay out no more than their due on behalf of all Australians. Now, the Liberal and National parties are opposing privacy rights but not, I suggest, because of any opposition to invasion of privacy.

The coalition has said nothing about the large number of private enterprise data collection agencies which have gathered all sorts of information about Australians-their data records, financial positions, even possessions. That has been tolerated for many years. Is the Opposition opposing this legislation because it is associated with the Australia Card or because it opposes the protection of people's privacy? With the legislation passed yesterday and presented yesterday and today the Government commits itself to three things-to the establishment of a taxation system based on the principles of fairness and equity; to the creation and maintenance of a welfare system tailored to assist those genuinely in need; and, in working towards those objectives, to safeguarding civil liberties and privacy.

These privacy Bills before the House give testament to these commitments. The Bills are designed to regulate the collection, handling and use by Federal departments and agencies of information about individuals to provide them with a level of privacy protection that we do not now have. The protection of individual freedom ensured by these Bills in unheard of in Australia, and greater than those guaranteed by some other developed nations.

The spy or voyeur may now use modern technology to penetrate a person's house, place of employment or other areas of privacy which she or he occupies. This invasion is more offensive and more damaging than anything which can be achieved by the peeping Tom or trespasser, and yet under existing law agents are able to pry with virtual impunity, using sophisticated technological means. These privacy Bills are important today as recent developments in technology and administration threaten more and more the privacy of the individual.

The scheme of the Privacy Bill is to set a series of rules called information privacy principles, which are based on the principles recommended by the Law Reform Commission in its draft legislation. They will apply to Federal departments and agencies. Under the principles, Commonwealth agencies must have a lawful purpose for collecting personal information, and the purpose must be related to the functions or activities of the collector. People must be made aware that information is being collected about them and they must ensure its accuracy. The principles require agencies to store information records securely against loss or misuse. There will be severe penalties for abuse of privacy and the Privacy (Consequential Amendments) Bill will make it impossible for a third party, not named in the Australia Card legislation, to gain access to database information without the express authority of the subject.

These Bills, in conjunction with the Australia Card, will ensure less intrusive methods of data collection-not more intrusive-and they will ensure its safe keeping. These assurances do not exist at present. However, the Australia Card, with this legislation, will change that situation. People will have access to their own data; they will be able to change inaccurate information; and they will at least have some control over their privacy. Today there are no such controls and the Bills will provide greater freedoms in the public place to combat developments such as the extension of powers granted to administrative officials; new practices which seek out a person's personal place or personal space; rapid development of technological means for penetrating place and space making it simply impossible to keep things private by locking a door; and development of computers to handle personal information with no controls on the use of, access to and flow of that information.

The Government's privacy legislation is the first serious attempt by an Australian government to legislate for the preservation of privacy of information stored on a computer database. It will accompany the Australia Card legislation, providing an assurance of privacy that was not guaranteed before the introduction of all these related Bills. The freedom of the individual and individual privacy will be greater under these related Bills than ever before. They were drafted for the Australia Card and, with the Australia Card Bill, they will mean greater privacy. It is about time the Opposition declared the truth of the matter. The invasion of personal privacy has been at danger level for some years but nothing was done by the Opposition, when in government, to curb it. The present Hawke Labor Government, concerned with the privacy of the individual, will enshrine privacy rights in legislation. I am pleased to support the legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am very pleased to be able to speak, if only briefly, on the Privacy Bill 1986 and the Privacy (Consequential Amendments) Bill 1986, which are important Bills. To date we have heard the ramblings of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and many Government members about certain academic aspects of the Privacy Bill. I will draw the attention of this House to what it really means and what we are really talking about. This legislation fits hand in glove with the Government's proposal to photograph and number every man, woman and child in Australia. This legislation is meant to reassure some people in the Australian community that, when they are numbered and photographed and their photograph is digitised and stored away on the Big Brother computer, everything will be fine because only selected public servants will have access to it.

SPEECH.PARA: That may be true. It may be true that we will have to have a certain security clearance or grading to go into the file, we may have to have an access number, such as No. 234567-that may in fact be the Prime Minister's number or even the number of the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel (Mrs Kelly), who is at the table-and we may leave a tail indicating that we have accessed that information. But the Government has not said that once we have accessed that information and we have it on hard copy-it is not longer on electronic disc but on hard copy; that is, it is printed out on a piece of paper-there is absolutely no restriction on our taking it to the nearest photocopier, putting it on that photocopier, selecting six, 10 or 150 copies and distributing those copies anywhere we like. I would be interested to hear the Minister's comments at the conclusion of this debate as to how the Government intends to control access to photocopiers by people who have access to the data file because I think it is a very important consideration. It is all very well to talk about whether we can get into the information in the first place but how do we control what people do with it once they have it?

A lot of nonsense has been talked about how we can build a super-secure system because we have seen how super-secure systems fall down. I remember reading in newspapers recently about how teenagers aged 14 in America-computer hackers, obviously, very intelligent young people-have bought equipment, much the same as is sold by Dick Smith, through mail order catalogues and have been able to crack various bank codes and transfer money into their own accounts. They have actually been able to crack the hotline between Washington and the Soviet Union. The latest thing that I have read about is that some West German computer experts have actually been able to crack the National Aeronautics and Space Administration (NASA) computer system. NASA deals with some very sensitive and high technology material and it has a very sophisticated security system. On a scale of 1 : 10 it probably has a security system that rates 9.5 yet it has been broken into.

The Prime Minister and the members of this Government ask us to believe that they will make the telecommunications network more secure than the NASA system. I represent the far north coast of New South Wales and I frequently have to use the subscriber trunk dialling system. I would like $1 for every crossed line I have ever had. We are talking about the ability to get into the telecommunications network.

The Government has been talking about dedicated lines. Let me tell honourable members exactly what a dedicated line is. It is a line which is part of the communications network. I guess in symbolic terms it is a line that runs parallel with a line that takes a telephone conversation but this line is used for data transmission. It does not carry voices, it carries electronic impulses. Those electronic impulses will refer to the data that will be on the computer, such as the identity and the other characteristics of every man, woman and child in Australia. This line is not in a separate trench and it is not a particular or unique network. The Australian Telecommunications Commission has not suddenly decided that it will spend billions of dollars digging holes around Australia in which to put this line. It is part of its communications network and in some cases it might even be part of the microwave link. It will have an encryption device on it which is just like a scrambler on a telephone that messes up the electronic signals, so that if someone goes into the line without having a de-encryption device the information will not make a lot of sense to that person.

The Prime Minister, on a number of occasions in this place, has put great store on these encryption devices for his electronic data transmission. I inform the House and everybody listening to the debate that Ted Turner, a New Zealand electronics millionaire, who has just challenged the San Diego Yacht Club to a race in maxi-yachts, made his money selling de-encryption devices-quite cheaply too, for only a couple of hundred dollars. These devices are available literally in an electronics mail order catalogue. They can be bought and plugged into a system and some of them are sophisticated enough actually to search through the pattern and work out how to de-encrypt-that is, decode-the data into which they have been plugged. Of course, we are relying on the technical expertise and, dare I say it, the reliability of the Telecom Australia network to protect the identity of all Australians.

Something occurred to me the other day when I learnt that the electronic data that will be stored will contain a digitised photograph. I have had some experience with computers. I have installed a couple of systems myself and I am well aware of what happens when one gets what is called in the trade, finger errors. They are punching errors and they occur when young ladies or young men who are actually including this information on the electronic disc, or however it is being stored, hit the wrong button. We are talking about a digitised photograph. We have in this record a name, a number and a few other bits of data plus the photograph. If the person involved is distracted, hits the wrong button and puts the wrong photograph next to that information, pity help the person concerned. The computer will say that No. 3456 has blond hair, but if the wrong photograph is put next to that number I do not really know how one would go about proving that one was that person. The computer will decide whether characteristics correspond to a digitised photograph. We will have the devil's own job proving who is who in that situation because the computer will have the benefit of the doubt. The computer will be the basis for testing information. I suppose what a person could do is get his mother or father or maybe the 50 or 60 other people who know him to come along to bear witness that in fact the photograph stored on the computer is wrong. I think the potential for that sort of error is quite significant.

I wonder when people will start talking about the possibility of what amounts to clerical errors. We will have 16 million files. Those files will be interrelated. We will have to relate fathers and mothers to their children. This already is part of the Medicare system. I wonder how far this system will go. I remember the then Minister for Health, the present Minister for Community Services and Health (Dr Blewett), saying categorically at the time the Medicare card was introduced that it would not be the first step towards an identification system. I am pleased that it was not because there are 20,000 more Medicare cards than there are people. However, it was in fact a trial run for the ID card system. I wonder whether we can believe anything we are told by the Minister for Community Services and Health or, in fact, anything we are told by the Government in relation to the ID system. We are talking about how the card will be used. The Government sets great store by the fact that there is nothing in the Bill that requires a person to carry the card. I wonder whether if we do that habitually there will be a record on our file to say that we have destroyed more than one ID card in the past. I wonder what the consequences for doing that will be.

I think it is a stack of nonsense to talk about protecting privacy. It was only late last year that we learnt that the entire records of the Department of Social Security in Victoria were for sale. Someone had managed to go in, perhaps one weekend, and to push the relevant button on the computer and get the records. It was only recently that we learnt that the Canadian tax files had been stolen. Someone put those files in a brief case and walked out of the office one Friday afternoon.
